0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Varicose veins of lower extremity: (Asclera[TM] injectable, spider veins, 1 mm or less in diameter) inject 0.1 to 0.3 mL of 0.5% solution IV into each vein intended for sclerosis; MAX 10 mL per treatment session
  • Varicose veins of lower extremity: (Asclera[TM] injectable, reticular veins, 1 to 3 mm in diameter) inject 0.1 to 0.3 mL of 1% solution IV into each vein intended for sclerosis; MAX 10 mL per treatment session
  • Varicose veins of lower extremity: (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) inject up to 5 mL IV using ultrasound guidance; MAX 5 mL per injection, 15 mL per session; separate repeat treatment sessions by at least 5 days

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions, some severe and fatal, have been reported; increased risk with use of larger volumes (greater than 3 mL of IV solution); monitor patient for at least 10 minutes following injection
  • tissue ischemia, necrosis, or gangrene may occur with intra-arterial injection or extravasation; patients with underlying arterial disease (eg, peripheral arteriosclerosis, thromboangiitis obliterans) may be at increased risk; consult vascular surgeon immediately if intra-arterial injection occurs (IV foam)
  • venous thrombosis may occur; increased risk in patients with reduced mobility, recent (within 3 months) major surgery, a history of DVT or pulmonary embolism, prolonged hospitalization, or pregnancy; monitoring recommended (IV foam)
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Dermatologic:Injection site bruising (foam, 15.4%; solution, 42%), Injection site irritation (41%), Injection site pain (10.7% to 24%), Injection site pigmentation change (38%), Injection site pruritus (19%)
Serious
Immunologic:Anaphylaxis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Polidocanol, a non-ionic detergent, is a sclerosing agent that produces endothelial damage in a concentration- and volume-dependent manner. Following injection of polidocanol into the vein, platelets aggregate and attach to the venous wall forming a dense network of platelets, cellular debris, and fibrin which subsequently occlude the vein. The occluded vein is then replaced with connective fibrous tissue. The injectable foam of polidocanol (Varithena[TM]) that is part of the drug/device combination product displaces blood from the vein prior to the release of the sclerosing agent, polidocanol.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono: Tmax (Varithena[TM]): within 15 minutes (after first dose); within 5 minutes (after second dose)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • (Asclera[TM] injectable) for IV use only
  • (Asclera[TM] injectable) using a syringe with a fine needle (26- or 30-gauge); insert tangentially into the vein and inject slowly
  • (Asclera[TM] injectable) apply gentle pressure during injection to prevent vein rupture; following removal of the needle and covering of the injection site, apply compression with a bandage or stocking and maintain compression for 2 to 3 days (spider veins) or 5 to 7 days (reticular veins) to reduce the risk of DVT
  • (Asclera[TM] injectable) patient should walk for 15 to 20 minutes following treatment; patient should be monitored during this period for potential allergic or anaphylactic reaction
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam, for IV use under ultrasound guidance only
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) do not shake the canister
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) use a new transfer unit for each session; use a new sterile syringe after each injection
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) 16 to 22 gauge and 40- to 50-mm IV catheter or micropuncture sets are recommended for venous access
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) prefill manometer tube with sterile heparinized NS solution and connect to the IV catheter; confirm venous access via aspiration with a syringe
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) elevate patient leg to approximately 45 degrees
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) remove canisters from pouch and place upright, removing safety clip from between canisters
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) twist canisters together clockwise until they come to a stop and the marks on the collars are aligned to start gas transfer
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) maintain canisters in upright position for exactly 1 minute while the they are gassing; during this time, open a new Varithena(TM) Transfer Unit blister pack, but leave it in the package
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) after 1 minute, twist the 2 canisters together by turning them the opposite direction of the previous twisting (counterclockwise)
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) separate the upper (oxygen, white collar) canister from the lower (polidocanol, blue collar) canister by pulling upright; leave the polidocanol canister in an upright position; record date and time on the label
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) remove transfer unit and immediately place on top of the blue polidocanol canister by gently rotating the unit clockwise until it drops into the collar threads; twist the unit clockwise until it reaches a stop; the system is now activated and ready for use
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) foam may be generated for immediate use once the cannula is in situ, the patient's leg is elevated, and the saphenofemoral junction is under ultrasound view
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) connect new 10-mL low-silicone syringe to transfer unit; prime syringe with downward pressure on unit to produce foam; fill syringe to between 3 and 5 mL; push syringe plunger to fully discard contents back into unit's waste container.
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) hold syringe plunger in place; apply downward pressure to transfer unit to begin purge cycle; do not pull back on the syringe plunger (ie, do not aspirate the foam); inspect foam within transfer unit to assure visible air bubbles have been expelled (less than 1 second); release plunger allowing syringe to fill to desired volume (up to 5 mL); wait 10 seconds to allow pressure to equalize before removing syringe from transfer unit
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) before injecting, inspect syringe for visible bubbles, and if present, discard foam and refill from transfer unit
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) administer injectable foam within 75 seconds of extraction from canister
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) may administer up to 5 mL per injection and up to 15 mL per session under ultrasound guidance; inject at a rate of approximately 1 mL/second in the great saphenous vein or 0.5 mL/second in accessory veins and varicosities
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) apply compression bandaging and stockings and have the patient walk for at least 10 minutes; maintain compression for 2 weeks posttreatment
  • (Varithena[TM] injectable foam) separate treatment sessions by at least 5 days
  • do not remove transfer unit from the canister if the canister is to be stored; the activated canister may be stored at room temperature for 7 days with a transfer unit in place; replace transfer unit just prior to next treatment session

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in appearance of uncomplicated spider veins and uncomplicated reticular veins is indicative of efficacy
  • improvement in the symptoms of superficial venous incompetence is indicative of efficacy
  • ultrasound; to guide injection of foam and to confirm venospasm of treated vein
  • walking; for 10 to 20 minutes after treatment
  • severe allergic reactions (including anaphylactic reaction), for at least 10 minutes after administration
  • venous thrombosis; after treatment with IV foam

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Intravenous injection side effects may include injection site hematoma, irritation, discoloration, pain, pruritus, and warmth. Intravenous foam side effects may include pain/discomfort in extremity, injection site thrombosis (retained coagulum), injection site hematoma or pain, superficial thrombophlebitis, and extravasation.
  • Warn the patient treated with IV injection to avoid heavy exercise, sunbathing, long airplane flights, and hot baths or saunas for 2 to 3 days after the procedure.
  • Instruct patients treated with IV injection to wear thigh-high or knee-high compression stockings or support hose continuously for 2 to 3 days after treatment and then for 2 to 3 weeks during the day.
  • Instruct patients treated with IV foam to keep posttreatment bandages dry and in place for 48 hours and to wear compression stockings on the treated legs continuously for 2 weeks.
  • Advise the patient treated with IV foam to avoid heavy exercise for 1 week and extended periods of inactivity for 1 month.
  • Advise patient to walk for at least 15 to 20 minutes (10 minutes for IV foam) after administration and then daily for the following few days (or a month for IV foam).
